webTitle: Australian men are leaners not lifters in the housework department

fields.standfirst: Hilda survey finds while we're less dependent on welfare, many males need to brush up on their domestic duties
fields.body:
The Household, Income and Labour Dynamics in Australia (Hilda) survey released each year provides a great view of how the nation is changing. The latest survey released earlier this week shows we are becoming less dependent upon welfare, but that there are signs inequality is increasing. It also found Australian men continue to be much lazier around the house than women.

The Hilda survey has been running since 2001 and involves interviewing the same households each year. In effect it is a mini census. By using the same sample each year it is able to, for example, look not just at inequality in a single year, but to examine income mobility (the ability for individuals to improve their income position from one year to the next), and also to look at individual’s “permanent income” (essentially the long term income level rather than one subject to one-off increases or declines).

The survey found that individuals pretty much stay in the same income percentile every year (or crudely, the rich stay rich and the poor stay poor). It also found that there has been a slight increase in the ratio of the income of wealthier households to poorer ones.

The ratio of the permanent income of the median households (p50) to the households in the 10th percentile (ie 90% of households earn more than it) was relatively flat to the GFC-stable equality. But the impact of the GFC has seen the permanent income of the median households increasing faster than the poorest household:

Similarly the permanent income of households in the 90th percentile is increasing faster than in median income households. This would suggest increasing inequality – a finding supported by the Hilda survey measure of the Gini coefficient. While the yearly Gini coefficient bounces up and down a bit, permanent income inequality has steadily been rising over the past decade:

The rise over time is only slight, and the GFC did briefly see the yearly rate fall – mostly due to rises in pensions and benefits and falls in the highest income levels. But in 2010 and 2011 the norm of increasing inequality appears to have returned.

One trend which shows little sign of changing is Australians’ declining dependence on welfare. Contrary to all the fears and invective from Joe Hockey, Kevin Andrews and others in the government, fewer households and individuals are on welfare than in the past, and the dependence of households on welfare has also declined:

Similarly when we look at who is receiving welfare, the treasurer’s arguments that the welfare system is too broad once again falls to pieces:

While households in the bottom income quintile (ie the poorest 20%) receive around 70% of their income from welfare, the drop off in welfare dependence is astonishingly fast. Those in the median quintile receive around just 12% of their income from welfare benefits.

This closely matches the findings by the OECD I noted on Monday. With this amount of data on the issue, to continue to suggest Australia’s welfare system is poorly targeted and too broad begins to involve worrying levels of delusion.

The Hilda survey also breaks down household income sources by family type. Here we find the overwhelming likelihood of dependence on welfare is determined by age and whether or not you are in a single parent household:

While the average household gets 23% of its income from welfare benefits, elderly households get on average anywhere from 48% to 60% from welfare. Incidentally the Hilda survey found that the reliance of those over 65 years of age on the aged pension has also declined since 2001.

In 2001 80% of those over 65 received the pension and it contributed on average 67% of their income. In 2001 77% were on the pension and on average just 60% of their income came from it.

But the above average reliance of single parents on welfare (around 50% of such household’s income comes from welfare) is also reflected in their above average poverty levels. The Hilda survey defines relative poverty if their household equivalised income is less than 50% of the median household equivalised income. At this (admittedly arbitrary) level they suggest such households are “unable to afford the goods and services needed to enjoy a normal or mainstream lifestyle in the country in which they live”.

On this measure single-parent households are the only household to show any significant increase in poverty levels this:

The survey notes that poverty rates rose “particularly from 2007, which coincides with the period of operation of the ‘welfare-to-work’ reforms”. Among these changes was theshifting of some lone parents from the parenting pension onto Newstart.

In 2013 the Gillard government broadened these moves. That tranche of single parents is not included in these figures though the data suggests that the likely outcome of the policy is for the poverty rates of single parents households to increase.

And given in 2007, 87% of single parents were women, it’s pretty clear who the changes hit the most. It would be nice if I could say that at least those women in a couple at least are having someone share the load, but when we look at the level of housework done by men and women, it’s brutally clear that men drop the ball.

In households where men are the main breadwinners, they do only 14.5 hours of housework a week compared to 27.6 hours by the woman in that household. While that might seem fair, when we look at households where women are the main breadwinner, the imbalance is revealed.

In those households men do around 17.5 hours a week of housework, but women do 21.5hours.

Even worse, these hours do not count childcare time. There the imbalance is even more pronounced. In households where women are the main breadwinners, the men on average spend nearly 13 hours a week caring for their children, compared to women who spend on average nearly 22.5 hours.

It would be good if I could mansplain this all by saying, yeah but men work more hours in paid employment. But when you combine hours worked in employment, housework and childcare, men come off looking like a bunch of lazy, couch-lying, TV-watching sloths:

In households where men and women earn roughly equal amounts, men work on average 43 hours compared to women who work 36 hours. But then in housework and childcare, men do a mere 28.3 hours compared to the women who do nearly 57 hours.

Sure the survey found men are a bit better than we used to be, but geez, 28 hours to 57? Good luck, men, trying to justify that.

webTitle: Vince Cable hits out at Bank of England over loans to small business

fields.bodyText: Vince Cable has rebuked the Bank of England on Wednesday for blocking reforms to lending rules that currently favour mortgages over loans to small businesses. The business secretary said the regulator stood in the way of changes to banking sector regulations that demand lenders keep bigger reserves to support business lending than they do for residential mortgage loans. In a speech in London, Cable said high street bank chiefs had warned him that business lending was unlikely to increase while draconian capital requirement rules treated business customers as a higher risk than mortgage borrowers. He said: "The way the regulatory system operates has undoubtedly had a suffocating effect on business lending and particularly on our exporters. "Not surprisingly, the result is that banks pump out lending in the mortgage market, while lending to small businesses is restricted. This directly stems from the rules on which the regulatory model is based and has had a very damaging impact." He said the Bank refused to bend rules to favour small businesses because they were set internationally and could not be amended. The Bank of England believes lending to small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs) is more risky by its nature and requires higher capital to guard against bad loans. But it has previously argued that banks with larger reserves enjoy lower capital costs and can therefore arrange cheaper lending to customers. It has also offered capital relief on new SME lending for banks that participate in the funding-for-lending scheme. "I'm not suggesting there is some perverse individual blocking all this. I just think the situation could be freed up and the decision-makers are sitting inside the Bank," said Cable. He also warned that an early rise in interest rates could put the economic recovery at risk, the Telegraph reported. "If these incipient inflationary pressures lead to a rise in interest rates sooner and further than is warranted by the economy as a whole, it could place in jeopardy our hopes for a sustained and balanced recovery," he said. The business secretary has campaigned for the government to take a more robust approach to boost business lending. He has set up a business bank, which has lent £780m and is involved in a pilot to use government funds to underwrite SME lending by commercial lenders. "This would allow banks to lend significantly more with the same capital buffer," he said. Adam Marshall, director of policy at the British Chambers of Commerce, said: "Vince Cable's remarks are encouraging to all those who believe that access to finance still bedevils many new and growing companies across the UK. "More can and must be done to increase the responsiveness of our banking system to the needs of the real economy. As our own research shows, banks still face significant challenges in reconnecting with many businesses. Greater competition, more proportionate regulatory requirements and the rebuilding of relationships and trust all have a role to play." Marshall said the business bank should be "radically scaled up" and added: "It must get closer to UK businesses and their needs, and have the ability to work directly with companies in some instances if it is to become a truly game-changing institution. Scaling up and strengthening the business bank must be a top priority in future years, no matter who forms Britain's next government."
